captions.text:
When YouTube started demonetising basically
any usage of (the F Word), I really thought I could cope.

I thought the methadone of saying things
like &quot;noob gobbles&quot; instead would tide me over.

But there really are times when
nothing will do the job but a good hard (not the F word).

So here&#39;s the deal, I&#39;m going to start
saying (Rated R words) again, but you&#39;ll only hear it

uncensored in the subscribers version, cause
the extra money means we can tell YouTube to stick

their demonetisation up there.... (Nostril)
As well as meaning you don&#39;t have to put up with

(dastardly!) sponsors. So head
over to Patreon and (jollywell) sign up!!!!
[Intro Music]

I&#39;ve often noted that retro-style media is
always nostalgic for a period roughly 20 years ago,

hence 90s-style boomer shooters being in for
a while cause it makes 35 year old game designers

nostalgic for that time they made a custom
level for Doom based on their high school and ended up

in Guantanamo Bay, but like a walrus in a food
coma rolling down a hill, the nostalgia wave always

moves on. And exactly 20 years ago the PC
boomer shooters were seeding ground to the rise of the

console shooter, and third person shooters
such as Max Payne, in which the camera hovered overhead

like a fussy mum with an overly stocked first
aid kit. Slow motion bullet time combat was pioneered

to compensate for the lack of a mouse and
console uses being generally slower of thought from all

the time they spent chewing the paint off
of their wave birds, and the main character was

rather self-indulgently modelled on the
game&#39;s lead designer with a look on his face like he

was hoping binge eating sour gummies would
help his chronic constipation. And now, inevitably,

we have a new retro indie shooter that
takes a very obvious and openly acknowledged influence

from Max Payne, especially the self-indulgent
bit, El Paso Elsewhere, designed by Xalavier Nelson,
in which we play paranormal detective James

Savage, voiced by Xalavier Nelson,
as he bullet time dual

pistols his way through level after level
of monster-haunted labyrinths to the tune of an

original hip hop soundtrack composed and
performed by Xalavier Nelson. And the plot is, James Savage

has to save the world by confronting his
evil bloodsucking vampire bitch of an ex-girlfriend.

And if I were any of Xalavier Nelson&#39;s
former partners I&#39;d certainly be narrowing my eyes

at this point. &quot;Self-indulgent&quot; is the word
of the day, and that certainly comes across over

the 50-odd levels of James Savage&#39;s
angsty monologuing in a voice like a bloke when the

blocked nose trying to seduce the microphone
in the middle of a noisy building site. The exact
method by which his evil ex-girlfriend is

attempting to destroy the
world is a bit unclear. One might

almost think that aspect of the plot was
included solely to turn James Savage&#39;s masturbatory airing

out of his personal issues into an act of
self-sacrificing heroism. So this all might come across

as a bit cringe-worthy, especially when the
self-penned hip hop tracks kick in, and we hear lyrics

that one might imagine scroll across the
back of Xalavier Nelson&#39;s high school homework diary.

But get past all that, and El Paso
Elephantine plays like a fun, snacky arcade shooter.

Arcade being a nice way of saying
&quot;repetitive&quot;,
but it&#39;s sort of impressive that they squeezed 50

levels out of about four visual themes and
ten furniture assets. The max pain-style high-octane

shooting comes across well enough, complete
with slow motion bullet dive, which you&#39;ll swiftly

learn is completely pointless because you can
turn slow motion on and off at any time, and diving
kinda messes with your aim, but hey, it looks

cool. It&#39;s one of those
games that&#39;s very hard to stop

playing once you start. You say &quot;okay, I&#39;ll
quit after this level &#39;cause I think my kids got into the

steak knives&quot; and then four or five levels
later you&#39;re like &quot;oh well, sounds like at least one of

them&#39;s still alive&quot;. And I put that down to
the game&#39;s simplicity. Explore a maze, shoot everything
in it. It&#39;s like Pac-Man having a Vietnam

flashback. And it flows
well because between the slow-mo and most

enemies dying in two or three shots and
ammunition boxes practically bleeding out of the skirting

boards, it&#39;s a surprisingly easy game. I
say surprisingly &#39;cause when editor Nick and I first

played the demo at GDC we both found it
really hard in a Hotline Miami kinda way. I&#39;d hate to

think Xalavier Nelson scaled the difficulty
back before release cos all the game journalists were

crapping out at it. Game journalists in the
middle of a convention who&#39;ve been alternating between
jogging to hotel room demos and freebasing heroin

don&#39;t make a good
control group. So final summary,

El Paso Elderberry is
a fun if repetitive callback
shooter that&#39;s essentially the nightmare sequence

from Max Payne drawn out for six or seven
hours, and while the story frequently has the air of

Xalavier Nelson&#39;s Geocities poetry page, that
also makes it feel very personal. Which I&#39;d take any

day over the usual committee-designed drivel.
That&#39;s about as personal as an industrial sheep dip.

And of the two games I want to talk about
this week it is undoubtedly the good one. Although

frankly, that&#39;s not worth much, cause the
other game compares unfavourably to a Ryvita smeared with
catarrh. The game isâ€¦ Right, well I have to pause

things there because I
had this whole review ready

to go but then a day before it was due I was
informed that the game&#39;s embargo date had changed.

I didn&#39;t play any other games this week nor
do I have the time to make an entire other review,

so please enjoy the scheduled review with
all identifying elements removed. Why not have fun

trying to guess what it is? Here&#39;s a hint,
it&#39;s not Armored Core 6. A game I&#39;ve been wanting to

talk about because I&#39;m
pretty sure it&#39;s completely

(flipping) terrible. [INSERT GAME NAME HERE]
 is what happens when someone

tries to knock off Hades without having
the slightest clue what makes Hades good. So it&#39;s

a roguelite dungeon crawler in which
(Jack Packard?)
descends through a sequence of randomised levels while

collecting blessings from associated god-like
entities, except there&#39;s only like three blessings

total so you usually
get all of them in every run.

And none of them do
anything to fundamentally alter

the core gameplay which consists of running up
to dudes and biffing them in the mush. Seven billion

times. It&#39;s a beat&#39;em up with a third
person over the shoulder camera which isn&#39;t great for

visibility but is perfect if you&#39;re really
curious about the contours of (JM8&#39;s?) his bathrobe, and

every room in every level is the same. Some
shitty one-hit kill minions you needn&#39;t worry about and

two or three big lads with spongy health bars
and basically the same attacks. You pick one at the
latter and start duffing them up but with a

control system that feels
like (Frost?) is immersed to the
waste in marshmallow fluff and has the leashes of

two large curious dogs
tied to his wrists. And yet

the game&#39;s still insultingly easy because
the enemy AI&#39;s as formidable as a large curious dog

trying to lick a piece of kibble out of a
hairbrush. So in contrast to El Paso Emerald Hill Zone,

(a game) is the bad kind of repetitive. It&#39;s
like trying to eat an entire bucket of gravel through

a straw. I got through all four dungeons
on my second go whereupon the game went &quot;Oh no,

a plot development! Go through all four
dungeons again but slightly bigger!&quot; So I did that without

a single death and the game went &quot;Oh no,
another plot development! Time to take the fight to the

main baddie! I don&#39;t suppose we do that by
going through all four dungeons a third time!&quot; Hey,

did you peek behind my DM screen? This time
through I died once during the final boss because

I committed the classic
mistake of forgetting not to

clip through the floor
during the opening cutscene.

(Secret Game) is the kind of bad that makes
me paranoid. Like, maybe I missed something,

maybe there was a checkbox in the options menu
labelled &quot;Remove Shittiness&quot;, maybe I didn&#39;t notice

the tutorial message for the &quot;Activate
Jetpack&quot; button. Because the alternative is that an entire

studio got through the development and
release of a game with a relatively well-known IP attached

that presumably has its own controllers
keeping an eye on things, and at no point did anyone else

raise a hand and say &quot;Has anyone else noticed
how a game&#39;s a load of old flystruck sheep placenta?&quot;

I don&#39;t know if I want to live in that
world. I mean, what if I have a medical emergency around

such people they&#39;d probably get
confused and stick chewable vitamins up my arse.
[Outro Music]
THIS VIDEO WAS MADE POSSIBLE BY
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
